Process Chemistry

Chlorine disinfects the water prior to discharging into the distribution lines. The chlorine dosage is determined by onsite testing.

The general chlorination equation is as follows:

Cl2 + H2O HOCl + H+ + Cl-

This equilibrium equation is the dominant one in chlorine from vacuum chlorinators with a pH of 2 to 3 and at the instant contact when chlorine is added to any water for disinfection. The free chlorine dominates the nature of the reaction. This often results in the development of noxious compounds such as nitrogen trichloride, NCl3. In dilute solution and at pH levels above about 4, the equilibrium shown above is displaced greatly to the right, and very little chlorine exists as such in solution. The hypochlorous acid formed is a weak acid and is very poorly dissociated at pH levels below 6.

Ammonia added to the water reacts with the hypochlorous acid to form monochloramine, which is the disinfection product according to the equilibrium equation:

NH3 + HOCL --> NH2Cl + H2O.

The disinfection process includes the chlorine supply, chlorinators, the ammonia supply, direct feed ammoniators, and injectors. The chlorine injector points are the controlling component. The injectors are used to create a vacuum that is used to draw the chlorine gas from the chlorine container through the chlorinator, and into the injector. The chlorinator meters the volume of chlorine solution at the injector, the chlorine dissolves in the injector water supply to form hypochlorous acid. From the injector, the hypochlorous acid solution flows to the point where it is injected into the pre-treated water. The differential pressure across the chlorinator (the measuring device) may be held constant or varied in accordance with the flow by changing the degree of vacuum.

Ammonia and chlorine are added while the filtered water is conveyed to the clearwell storage. Ammonia forms monochloramines from its reaction with the hypochlorous acid. Chloramines are a weaker disinfectant than chlorine and less reactive with organic materials present in water. An advantage of using chloramines as a disinfectant is the production of lower concentrations of disinfection by-products in the distribution system.

The contact time and the chlorine residual are the two principal factors involved in achieving effective viral, protozoan, and bacterial kill. The contact is usually specified by the USEPA and may range from 15 to 45 minutes. The appropriate chlorine residual is monitored and controlled by residual chlorine testing. System controls maintain 2 milligram per liter (mg/l) chlorine residual to provide continual protection throughout distribution from the treatment plant to the end-user tap.

Maximum Intended Inventory

The maximum intended inventory for chlorine is 120,000 pounds. The maximum intended inventory for anhydrous ammonia is 41,200 pounds.

3.3 Process Hazard Analysis

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) is required to be performed in accordance with accepted methodologies (i.e. What If Analysis). This PHA must be revalidated and updated once every 5 years and involves personnel operating the process. Provided there are no equipment, process or chemical changes, the PHA will be revalidated in 5 years, otherwise the PHA will be revalidated after equipment and process changes are implemented before the process is started up.

The PHA provisions of the PSM standard require that employers complete analyses of all affected processes in May 1997. The RMP rule recognizes hazard analyses performed to meet PSM requirements for a PHA, as an initial PHA under RMP.

The PHA documents recommendations to management to minimize or eliminate hazards, for mitigating the consequences of hazards of any releases or other unplanned events, and for reducing the likelihood of exposure to chlorine or other toxic materials. For each potential hazard identified, the PHA report describes:

?h The particular hazard;

?h Possible causes of the hazardous situation;

?h Potential consequences of the hazardous situation; and

?h !?Action items" based on the recommendations.

Resolution of recommendations will be documented, including documentation of actions to be taken and a written schedule of when actions are to be completed and when actions are completed. Communication of these actions will be conducted for operating, maintenance, and other employees whose work assignments are in the process and who may be affected by the recommendations or actions.

The two most recent PHAs (2004 and 2012) are provided in Appendix D. The most recent PHA was completed using a What-if checklist. Process controls in use include manual monitoring of the chlorine system and daily inspections of chlorine and anhydrous ammonia storage and use areas. Mitigation systems include the use of vacuum pressure for the chlorine system (when pressure is lost the system shuts down). Monitoring and detection systems are provided in Section 2.1 and Section 3.4.4.

Process Chemistry

Chlorine disinfects the water prior to discharging into the distribution lines. The chlorine dosage is determined by onsite testing.

The general chlorination equation is as follows:

Cl2 + H2O HOCl + H+ + Cl-

This equilibrium equation is the dominant one in chlorine from vacuum chlorinators with a pH of 2 to 3 and at the instant contact when chlorine is added to any water for disinfection. The free chlorine dominates the nature of the reaction. This often results in the development of noxious compounds such as nitrogen trichloride, NCl3. In dilute solution and at pH levels above about 4, the equilibrium shown above is displaced greatly to the right, and very little chlorine exists as such in solution. The hypochlorous acid formed is a weak acid and is very poorly dissociated at pH levels below 6.

Ammonia added to the water reacts with the hypochlorous acid to form monochloramine, which is the disinfection product according to the equilibrium equation:

NH3 + HOCL --> NH2Cl + H2O.

The disinfection process includes the chlorine supply, chlorinators, the ammonia supply, direct feed ammoniators, and injectors. The chlorine injector points are the controlling component. The injectors are used to create a vacuum that is used to draw the chlorine gas from the chlorine container through the chlorinator, and into the injector. The chlorinator meters the volume of chlorine solution at the injector, the chlorine dissolves in the injector water supply to form hypochlorous acid. From the injector, the hypochlorous acid solution flows to the point where it is injected into the pre-treated water. The differential pressure across the chlorinator (the measuring device) may be held constant or varied in accordance with the flow by changing the degree of vacuum.

Ammonia and chlorine are added while the filtered water is conveyed to the clearwell storage. Ammonia forms monochloramines from its reaction with the hypochlorous acid. Chloramines are a weaker disinfectant than chlorine and less reactive with organic materials present in water. An advantage of using chloramines as a disinfectant is the production of lower concentrations of disinfection by-products in the distribution system.

The contact time and the chlorine residual are the two principal factors involved in achieving effective viral, protozoan, and bacterial kill. The contact is usually specified by the USEPA and may range from 15 to 45 minutes. The appropriate chlorine residual is monitored and controlled by residual chlorine testing. System controls maintain 2 milligram per liter (mg/l) chlorine residual to provide continual protection throughout distribution from the treatment plant to the end-user tap.

Deficiencies in equipment that are outside acceptable limits (as defined by the process safety information found in Sec. 68.65 of the CAA) are corrected before further use or in a safe and timely manner when necessary means are taken to assure safe operation.

3.6.4 Quality Assurance

Equipment used to store, process, or handle chlorine and ammonia will be designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to minimize the risk of accidental releases. The first line of defense available is to operate and maintain the process as designed and to keep the chlorine and ammonia contained.

In the construction of new equipment, assurance that equipment is suited for the process application for which they are intended will be conducted. Appropriate checks and inspections will be performed to assure that equipment is installed properly and consistent with design specifications and the manufacturer!|s instructions. Maintenance materials, spare parts, and equipment are suited for the process application for which they will be used.

3.7 Management of Change

A program has been implemented to prevent incidents caused by changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, or procedures. Management of Change requirements of the RMP/PSMP prohibits any changes to the chlorine or anhydrous ammonia systems without proper review.

The intent of Management of Change is to ensure that all modifications to equipment, procedures, raw materials and processing conditions concerning chlorine and anhydrous ammonia (other than replacement-in-kind) are assessed prior to implementation of the change. 3.8 Pre-Startup Review

A pre-startup safety review must be performed on new or modified processes to ensure that equipment and construction meet design specifications that procedures and training have been implemented, and that hazard analysis recommendations have been resolved.

It is important that a safety review takes place before chlorine or anydrous ammonia or any other highly hazardous substance regulated by OSHA and the USEPA is introduced into the process. The intent of this review procedure is to ensure that the requirements for startup of process elements after shutdown are clearly documented and provided to personnel associated with the system. The requirements of this section apply whenever the WTP is shutdown for routine and non-routine maintenance, whenever the process is modified or new chemicals are introduced into the process, or after an emergency shutdown of a system. The pre-startup safety review procedure is designed to ensure that a pre-startup review will be conducted before chlorine or anhydrous ammonia is introduced into the process for new and modified facilities when the modification necessitates a change to process safety information. This review will confirm the following:

?h Construction and installation of new equipment is in accordance with design specifications

?h Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate

?h A PHA (What-If study) conducted has been conducted and recommendations have been resolved for new or modified processes

?h Training of each employee involved in the process has been completed

A site committee will be established to conduct the review. As part of the pre-startup safety review, WTP management will assure that the construction and equipment is in accordance with specifications, and that the training of each employee involved in the operating process of this particular section has been completed. All modifications will be reviewed and a PHA will be conducted to verify that the chlorine or ammonia processes can be safely operated. The original PHA will be updated appropriately.

A Pre-Startup Safety Review form is provided in Appendix I. In the event that the Pre-Startup Safety Review

3.9 Compliance Audits

A key component of the RMP/PSMP compliance audit program is self-evaluation of program effectiveness on a periodic basis. The objective of the self-evaluation program is to ensure that a strong RMP/PSMP program is maintained, implemented, and followed by appropriate personnel. The RMP/PSMP will be reviewed at least every three years (per regulation).

Findings of the audit are documented along with appropriate response to each finding along with documentation for correction of deficiencies. The assessment includes a review of all program elements as presented in this RMP/PSMP. Team members that participate in the Compliance Audit include the Plant Manager, Safety and Training Specialists, Water Operations Supervisor, and Maintenance Supervisor. The Plant Manager is responsible for providing written follow-up and completion of assessment findings.

A Compliance Audit Form and copies of current Compliance Audits that were conducted are provided in Appendix J. Ensure the form is completed and a hard copy is placed in Appendix J.

3.10 Incident Investigation

Incident investigation, reporting, and documentation procedures must be prepared and implemented for any incident that resulted in an emergency situation (chlorine and/or anhydrous ammonia release). Each incident from a covered process that resulted in deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage will be investigated and an incident investigation report filed in the RMP. The PSM standard and the RMP rule require that a comprehensive incident investigation program is in place to examine and correct deficiencies that may have allowed the incident to occur.

The OCWUT has developed a formal documented system to manage incident investigations, remedial activities, and follow up. An incident investigation must be initiated as soon as possible, but no later than 48 hours following the incident. All incidents involving the chlorine or anhydrous ammonia system must be reported to the Plant Manager immediately.

An incident investigation team will be established to thoroughly investigate and analyze each such incident. The membership of the investigation team will include at least one person knowledgeable in the process involved, including a contract employee if the incident involved work of the contractor, and other persons with appropriate knowledge and experience.

The investigation team must prepare a report at the conclusion of the investigation, which includes at a minimum:

?h Date of the incident

?h Date investigation began

?h A description of the incident

?h The factors that contributed to the incident

?h Any recommendations resulting from the investigation

The Incident Investigation Procedure is provided in Appendix K. Investigation reports (should there be a qualified release) are maintained by the Safety and Training Specialist and a copy will be provided in Appendix K. There have been no accidental releases within the past 5 years that qualify for inclusion in the RMP.

The report by the investigation team is reviewed with all affected personnel, whose job tasks are relevant to the incident findings, including contract employees where applicable.

In addition to an OCWUT investigation, a major release of chlorine or anhydrous ammonia may be investigated by the Chemical Safety Board. The Chemical Safety Board is an independent federal agency that investigates chemical accidents to protect workers, the public, and the environment. The Chemical Safety Board conducts root cause investigations at fixed industrial facilities. The causes are usually found to be deficiencies in safety management systems, equipment failures, human errors, or unforeseen chemical reactions. The agency does not issue fines or citations, but does make recommendations to plants, regulatory agencies such as OSHA and the USEPA, industry organizations, and labor groups. Congress designed the Chemical Safety Board to be non-regulatory and independent of other agencies so that its investigations might, where appropriate, review the effectiveness of regulations and regulatory enforcement.

Releases of reportable quantities should always be reported to the National Response Center, which is the sole federal point of contact for reporting oil and chemical spills (note: reportable quantity thresholds are provided in Section 4.2.3).

3.13.1 Owner or Operator Responsibilities

OCWUT and Lake Draper WTP management responsibilties include the following:

Safe work practices of contractors must comply with OCWUT safe work practices in covered process areas. A Contractor Safety Procedure is provided in Appendix M. Executive Summary

Lake Draper Water Treatment Plant (WTP) has adopted this Risk Management Program in order to implement 40 CFR 68, the federal requirements regulating Risk Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals. This Program will help prevent the occurrence of, or minimize the consequences of, catastrophic releases by stating our policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in start-up, operation, inspection, maintenance, and the other matters addressed in the federal standard.

This Executive Summary includes information required under 40 CFR 68.155.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The City of Oklahoma City Utilities Department implements a scheduled preventive maintenance program, including inspection and testing, to minimize the potential for accidental releases. Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) have been reviewed and revised to enable the employees to perform their work safely and efficiently and provide immediate corrective response to any accidents.

The Lake Draper WTP staff are trained to respond in the event of a chemical release incident. Emergency response to accidental releases is also coordinated with the Oklahoma City Police and Fire Departments and the State and Local Emergency Response Centers.

Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances

The Lake Draper WTP utilizes chlorine and anhydrous ammonia (regulated substances) as disinfectants in the drinking water treatment process.

The Process Hazard Analysis completed for this RMP documents the process and the findings to minimize or eliminate hazards, to mitigate the consequences of hazards of any releases or other unplanned events, and to reduce the likelihood of exposure to chlorine or anhydrous ammonia.

Written procedures and information have been developed, implemented, and maintained for each hazardous process, including steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions.

All employees involved in working with and around the chlorine and anhydrous ammonia systems are trained in process and safety procedures, including emergency response on an annual basis.

The mechanical integrity of chlorine and anhydrous ammonia process equipment is documented and maintained through maintenance, inspection, and testing programs.
